description: Large layered clusters 10-60 cm wide with multi-branched central stem from underground tuber-like base. Grayish-brown fan or spoon-shaped caps in rosette pattern. Angular white to yellowish pores, short white branching stems.
habitat: Primarily at base of oak trees (especially red oak), occasionally other hardwoods. Returns to same spot year after year. Most common in Northeastern US and Canada, found west to Idaho.
season: North America: Late summer to early fall, specifically September 1 to early November. Most prolific September-October in Eastern North America.
lookalikes: Meripilus sumstinei (Black-Staining Polypore) - EDIBLE but inferior - blackens when bruised (10-40 min), tougher/leathery texture, thicker fronds
Bondarzewia berkeleyi (Berkeley's Polypore) - EDIBLE - thick-fleshed, cream-colored, won't stain black
safety_notes: No poisonous lookalikes. Key identifier: does NOT stain black when bruised (unlike Meripilus). Best when young and tender. Clean thoroughly as debris collects in layers.
